}} 'Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation' ('Twentieth Century-Fox Film
Corporation', with hyphen, from 1935 to 1985)âalso known as '20th Century Fox',
or '20th Century Fox Pictures', is one of the six major American film studios .
Located in the Century City area of Los Angeles, just west of Beverly Hills, the
studio is currently a subsidiary of Rupert Murdoch's 21st Century Fox.

The company was founded on May 31, 1935, as the result
of the merger of 'Fox Film Corporation', founded by William Fox in 1915, and
'Twentieth Century Pictures', founded in 1933 by Darryl F. Zanuck and Joseph
M. Schenck.

Twentieth Century Fox's most popular film franchises include [[Star Wars]]
(until Disney's Acquisition of Lucasfilm), [[Ice Age (franchise)|Ice Age]], [[X-
Men (film series)|X-Men]], [[Die Hard (franchise)|Die Hard]], [[Alien
(franchise)|Alien]], and [[Planet of the Apes (franchise)|Planet of the Apes]].
Television series produced by Fox include [[The Simpsons]], [[M*A*S*H (TV
series)|M*A*S*H]], [[The X-Files]], [[Family Guy]], [[Buffy the Vampire
Slayer]], [[Glee (TV series)|Glee]], and [[24 (TV series)|24]]. Among the most
famous actresses to come out of this studio were Shirley Temple, who was 20th
Century Fox's first film star, Betty Grable, Gene Tierney, Marilyn Monroe and
Jayne Mansfield. The studio also contracted the first African-American cinema
star, Dorothy Dandridge. [[Rob & Bruce]]

20th Century Fox is a member of the Motion Picture Association of America
(MPAA).
